newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean president's son on trial for bribery.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean president's son on trial for bribery.

text.p: South Korean President Kim Young-sam's second son went on trial on charges of bribery and tax evasion on Monday in a scandal that analysts said could affect this year's presidential elections.
Dressed in pale blue prison garb and his head lowered, Kim Hyun-chul admitted accepting a total of 6.61 billion won ($7.4 million) from businessmen but denied any of the money was bribes.
"I was never asked for favours in return for the money I received," he told a Seoul criminal court.
Kim Hyun-chul's arrest last May dealt a serious blow to the credibility of his father ahead of presidential elections in December.

The president is barred from seeking re-election by the constitution, and political analysts said his son's arrest made it difficult for the president to try openly to install his protege as his successor.
Kim Young-sam's ability to shape South Korean politics has also been curtailed by a loans-for-kickbacks scandal involving failed Hanbo Steel Co.
State prosecutors accused the president's second son of taking kickbacks worth 3.22 billion won in return for favours, while accepting a further 3.39 billion won as gifts with no strings attached.
The younger Kim, nicknamed "the crown prince" by the local media, took his first kickback shortly after his father came to office in February 1993, according to the prosecution.

Also on trial is a former top intelligence official, Kim Ki-sup, an associate of the president's son, charged with receiving 150 million won in bribes to help obtain a business licence. He pleaded guilty to the charge.
Prosecutors said Kim Hyun-chul evaded taxes of 1.4 billion won on gifts from businessmen, hiding the money in accounts using borrowed names.
One of his father's first acts on taking power was to ban false-name accounts as part of his anti-graft campaign.

The move, aimed at flushing out vast sums of money squirrelled away during decades of corrupt rule by a military-backed government, led to the arrest and jailing of former presidents Roh Tae-woo and Chun Doo Hwan.
Opposition parties have alleged Kim Hyun-chul is the "real power" who pressured banks to keep loans flowing to Hanbo Steel, South Korea's second largest steelmaker.
The steelmaker's collapse in January shed light on a web of corruption involving politicians, bankers and businessmen.
Last month, the founder of Hanbo, key presidential aides, politicians and top bankers were jailed for their roles in the Hanbo scandal.

Prosecutors have cleared Kim Hyun-chul of any wrongdoing in the Hanbo affair but indicted him for accepting money in return for favours to businessmen in connection with cable television deals and a road-building contract.
Opposition parties allege the president's 1992 election campaign was partly financed by Hanbo, and that after massive overspending, unused election funds were laundered by Kim Hyun-chul.
President Kim has said a large sum was spent for the 1992 election but refused to yield to opposition demands to reveal details of his campaign spending.
South Korean laws call for a maximum penalty of life in jail for tax evasion. Under the bribery charges brought against him, Kim Hyun-chul faces a maximum five years in jail.
